5  Git & GitHub

5.1 Git & GitHub

5.1.1 Contents

  • GitHub Auth (new laptop)
  • GitHub connection on VM (clone/pull/push)
  • Enable push from the VM
  • Repo Setup on the VM
  • Daily VM Git workflow
  • Feature Branch Workflow (Recommended)
  • Quick Branch-To-Production Flow

5.2 GitHub Auth (new laptop)

5.2.1 Fix GitHub auth error on a new laptop

Error message:

remote: Invalid username or token.
Password authentication is not supported for Git operations.

This means Git is trying to use HTTPS + password. GitHub no longer accepts account passwords for Git operations.

5.2.2 Recommended fix (SSH)

  1. Check current remote:
git remote -v
  1. Create an SSH key (if you do not already have one):
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@biochem.mpg.de"
  1. Start agent and add the key:
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
  1. Copy public key and add it to GitHub:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

GitHub: Settings -> SSH and GPG keys -> New SSH key

  1. Switch repo remote to SSH:
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
  1. Test and pull:
ssh -T git@github.com
git pull origin main

5.2.3 Fallback fix (HTTPS + PAT)

If SSH is not possible, use a Personal Access Token (PAT), not your account password.

  1. Keep/set HTTPS remote:
git remote set-url origin https://github.com/yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
  1. Pull/push and enter:
  • Username: your GitHub username
  • Password: your PAT token
  1. Optional (store credentials on macOS keychain):
git config --global credential.helper osxkeychain

5.2.4 Quick sanity check

git remote -v
git fetch origin
git status

For VM-side Git troubleshooting (divergent branches, stash/pull, merge conflicts), see VM Troubleshooting Guide → Git / GitHub.

5.3 GitHub connection on VM (clone/pull/push)

Use SSH on the VM.

5.3.1 Step 1: Create a VM SSH key

mkdir -p ~/.ssh
chmod 700 ~/.ssh
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "<your-github-email>" -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm.pub

5.3.2 Step 2: Load key and pin it in SSH config

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm
cat >> ~/.ssh/config <<'EOF'
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm
  IdentitiesOnly yes
EOF
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/config

5.3.3 Step 3: Add key in GitHub

cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_bcfngs_vm.pub

Copy the full output (public key) and paste it in GitHub. Do not paste the private key file.

Choose one:

  1. Deploy key (read-only) on this repo: clone + pull only.
  2. User/account SSH key (write access): clone + pull + push.

Where to paste:

  • Deploy key: GitHub repo BCFNGS-project-management -> Settings -> Deploy keys -> Add deploy key.
  • User key: GitHub account -> Settings -> SSH and GPG keys -> New SSH key.

After choosing:

( for bcf-vm, we choose only deploy key, since we don’t plan to push changes from here.)

If we do make any local changes, we must run the following before pulling new changes (since they will probably fail)

git stash push -m "vm-local"
git pull --ff-only origin main
git stash pop
  • If you chose Deploy key (read-only):
cd /home/<user>
git clone git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git pull --ff-only origin main
  • If you chose User/account SSH key (write access):
cd /home/<user>
git clone git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout -b <your-branch>
git push -u origin <your-branch>

Recommendation:

  • On ngs-vm (production): use Deploy key (read-only).
  • On bcf-vm or local dev machines: use User/account key if you need push.

If you make local changes on a pull-only VM:

  • Changes remain local.
  • git pull can fail if local edits conflict with incoming changes.
  • Safe pull pattern:
cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git stash push -m "local-vm-work"
git pull --ff-only origin main
git stash pop

If stash pop conflicts, resolve conflicts manually.

5.3.4 Step 4: Verify access

ssh -T git@github.com
git ls-remote git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git

5.4 Enable push from the VM

If the VM currently uses a deploy key, push will be denied. To allow push, use an SSH key attached to a GitHub user that has write permission.

Set Git identity on the VM:

git config --global user.name "Assa Yeroslaviz"
git config --global user.email "yeroslaviz@biochem.mpg.de"
git config --global pull.rebase false

Optional write test:

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout -b test/vm-write-check
git push -u origin test/vm-write-check

If push succeeds, delete the test branch:

git checkout main
git branch -D test/vm-write-check
git push origin --delete test/vm-write-check

5.5 Repo Setup on the VM

Clone once:

cd /home/<user>
git clone git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git remote -v

If the repo already exists with HTTPS remote, switch it to SSH:

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git

Expected server layout:

/srv/shiny-server/
├── sequencing-app/
│ ├── app.R
│ ├── setup_database.R
│ ├── sequencing_projects.db
│ └── www/
  │ ├── logo.png
  │ └── minerva.png

5.6 Daily VM Git workflow

Pull latest main:

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout main
git pull --no-rebase origin main

Push your changes:

git checkout -b <your-branch>
git add .
git commit -m "your message"
git push -u origin <your-branch>

For pull conflicts/divergent branches, see Troubleshooting → Git / GitHub.

5.7 Feature Branch Workflow (Recommended)

Use this flow for new features and bug fixes.

5.7.1 Step 1: Start from updated main

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout main
git pull --ff-only origin main

5.7.2 Step 2: Create and switch to a feature branch

git checkout -b codex/<short-feature-name>

5.7.3 Step 3: Commit your work on the feature branch

git add <files>
git commit -m "<clear message>"

5.7.4 Step 4: Push branch and open PR

git push -u origin codex/<short-feature-name>

Open a Pull Request from codex/<short-feature-name> -> main.

5.7.5 Step 5: Test on VM from the same branch (optional but recommended)

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git fetch origin
git checkout codex/<short-feature-name>
git pull --ff-only origin codex/<short-feature-name>
PUBLIC_BASE_URL="https://<vm-hostname>" ./scripts/deploy.sh

5.7.6 Step 6: Merge PR, then sync local/VM to main

git checkout main
git pull --ff-only origin main

Optional cleanup:

git branch -d codex/<short-feature-name>
git push origin --delete codex/<short-feature-name>

5.8 Quick Branch-To-Production Flow

Use this as the short operational checklist for normal feature delivery.

5.8.1 Step 1: Start feature branch (local machine)

We first create feature branch locally.

cd /Users/yeroslaviz/Documents/Github/BCFNGS-project-management
# # Switches your working branch to main (or make sure I'm already in the branch)
git checkout main
# # --ff-only means “update only if this is a clean fast-forward.”.
# It prevents Git from creating an automatic merge commit during pull.
# This keeps history cleaner and avoids accidental branch divergence surprises.
git pull --ff-only origin main
# Creates a new branch with that name and immediately switches onto it
git checkout -b <feature-branch>

5.8.2 Step 2: Commit and push (local machine)

git add <files>

running git status here will show the results of what we added to the new branch

$git status

On branch additional-cost-notifications
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
        modified:   Documentation/chapters/change-log.qmd
        modified:   Documentation/chapters/deploy-operations.qmd
        modified:   Documentation/chapters/git-github.qmd
        modified:   sequencing-app/app.R
        modified:   sequencing-app/setup_database.R
git commit -m "<message>"
git push -u origin <feature-branch> # The `-u` sets upstream so future pushes can be just git push

5.8.3 Step 3: Test branch on test VM (bcf-vm or ngs-testing-vm)

The sequence would be: update remote info -> move to correct branch -> update branch safely.

cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git fetch origin # update remote info - Downloads latest remote refs/commits, but don't touch your working files.
# # Switches working branch (or creates/tracks local branch from remote).
git checkout --track origin/<feature-branch>   # first time only
# or: git checkout <feature-branch>            # if local branch already exists
# Integrates any new commits from remote into your local branch. --ff-only guarantees no merge commit is created accidentally.
git pull --ff-only origin <feature-branch>
PUBLIC_BASE_URL="https://<vm-hostname>" ./scripts/deploy.sh

Now, we can log in to the testing VM (e.g. bcf-vm) and test the new setting to see if everything works as expected. If we can see the new changes, continue to step 5 and merge the PR

5.8.4 Step 4: Merge PR on GitHub

This should only be done, after the changes were varified on the test VM and were sucessfully integrated.

The git push -u command from step 2 has this output:

Enumerating objects: 19, done.
Counting objects: 100% (19/19), done.
Delta compression using up to 8 threads
Compressing objects: 100% (10/10), done.
Writing objects: 100% (10/10), 6.28 KiB | 1.25 MiB/s, done.
Total 10 (delta 8), reused 0 (delta 0), pack-reused 0 (from 0)
remote: Resolving deltas: 100% (8/8), completed with 8 local objects.
remote:
remote: Create a pull request for 'additional-cost-notifications' on GitHub by visiting:
remote:      https://github.com/yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management/pull/new/additional-cost-notifications
remote:
To github.com:yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management.git
 * [new branch]      additional-cost-notifications -> additional-cost-notifications
branch 'additional-cost-notifications' set up to track 'origin/additional-cost-notifications'.

it automatically creates a pull request for the new branch.

Then:

  • Confirm base: main and compare: additional-cost-notifications.
  • Click Create pull request.
  • Review Files changed.
  • Click Merge pull request (or Squash and merge if you prefer one commit).
  • Click Confirm merge.

5.8.5 Step 5: Sync local main after merge

cd /Users/yeroslaviz/Documents/Github/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout main
git pull --ff-only origin main

5.8.6 Step 6: Deploy main to production (ngs-vm)

cd /home/yeroslaviz/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout main
git pull --ff-only origin main
PUBLIC_BASE_URL="https://ngs-vm.biochem.mpg.de" ./scripts/deploy.sh

5.8.7 Step 7: Optional branch cleanup

# local
git branch -d <feature-branch>

# remote
git push origin --delete <feature-branch>

# test VM (optional)
cd /home/<user>/BCFNGS-project-management
git checkout main
git branch -d <feature-branch>

5.8.8 Step 8: Keep unmerged feature branches in sync with main

If you keep a feature branch open while main keeps changing, sync main into that branch before final merge.

This apply for example if If I have a new branch were I test a new feature. I don’t merge it yet, but continue to modify the main branch.

Recommended (rebase):

git checkout <feature-branch>
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/main
git push --force-with-lease

Alternative (merge):

git checkout <feature-branch>
git fetch origin
git merge origin/main
git push

5.8.9 Notes

  • --ff-only avoids accidental merge commits on pull.
  • deploy.sh deploys code and restarts app; it does not rebuild DB.
  • Production deployment should use main unless an explicit pre-merge production test is required.
